html:
Etymology[edit]

From re- (“back; again”) +‎ spīrō (“breathe”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /resˈpiː.roː/, [rɛsˈpiː.roː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /resˈpi.ro/, [rɛsˈpiː.rɔ]

Verb[edit]

respīrō (present infinitive respīrāre, perfect active respīrāvī, supine respīrātum); first conjugation

  1. (transitive) I blow or breathe back; breathe out, exhale
  2. (intransitive) I breathe, respire
  3. (intransitive, figuratively) I recover breath; recover, revive
  4. (intransitive, figuratively) I abate, diminish, cease

Derived terms[edit]

  • respīrāculum
  • respīrāmen
  • respīrāmentum

Related terms[edit]

  • aspīrō
  • cōnspīrō
  • exspīrō
  • inspīrō
  • interspīrō

  • spīrō

Descendants[edit]

  • Asturian: respirar
  • Italian: respirare
  • Old French: respirer
    • → English: respire
    • Middle French: respirer
      • French: respirer
    • Norman: respither (Jersey)

  • Old Occitan: respirar
    • Catalan: respirar
    • Occitan: respirar
  • Piedmontese: respiré
  • Old Portuguese: respirar
    • Galician: respirar
    • Portuguese: respirar
  • Old Spanish: respirar
    • Spanish: respirar
  • Romanian: respira
  • Romansch: respirar, respirer

References[edit]

  • respiro in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • respiro in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • respiro in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • to recover from one's fright: a metu respirare (Cluent. 70. 200)
